elements.content: It is of profound significance with regard to the global energy crisis to develop new techniques and materials that can convert the chemical potential of water into other forms of energy, especially electricity. To address this challenge, we built a new type of energy transduction pathway (humidity gradients → mechanical work → electrical power) using moisture-responsive crystalline materials as the media for energy transduction. Single-crystal data revealed that a flexible zeolitic pyrimidine framework material, ZPF-2-Co, could undergo a reversible structural transformation (β to α phase) with a large unit cell change upon moisture stimulus. Dynamic water vapor sorption analysis showed a gate-opening effect with a steep uptake at as low as 10% relative humidity (RH). The scalable green synthesis approach and the fast water vapor adsorption–desorption kinetics made ZPF-2-Co an excellent sorbent to harvest water from arid air, as verified by real water-harvesting experiments. Furthermore, we created a gradient distribution strategy to fabricate polymer-hybridized mechanical actuators based on ZPF-2-Co that could perform reversible bending deformation upon a variation of the humidity gradient. This mechanical actuator showed remarkable durability and reusability. Finally, coupling the moisture-responsive actuator with a piezoelectric transducer further converted the mechanical work into electrical power. This work offers a new type of moisture-responsive smart material for energy transduction and provides an in-depth understanding of the responsive mechanism at the molecular level.
elements.clean_text:
It
is of profound significance with regard to the global energy
crisis to develop new techniques and materials that can convert the
chemical potential of water into other forms of energy, especially
electricity. To address this challenge, we built a new type of energy
transduction pathway (humidity gradients → mechanical work
→ electrical power) using moisture-responsive crystalline materials
as the media for energy transduction. Single-crystal data revealed
that a flexible zeolitic pyrimidine framework material, ZPF-2-Co, could undergo a reversible structural transformation (β to
α phase) with a large unit cell change upon moisture stimulus.
Dynamic water vapor sorption analysis showed a gate-opening effect
with a steep uptake at as low as 10% relative humidity (RH). The scalable
green synthesis approach and the fast water vapor adsorption–desorption
kinetics made ZPF-2-Co an excellent sorbent to harvest
water from arid air, as verified by real water-harvesting experiments.
Furthermore, we created a gradient distribution strategy to fabricate
polymer-hybridized mechanical actuators based on ZPF-2-Co that could perform reversible bending deformation upon a variation
of the humidity gradient. This mechanical actuator showed remarkable
durability and reusability. Finally, coupling the moisture-responsive
actuator with a piezoelectric transducer further converted the mechanical
work into electrical power. This work offers a new type of moisture-responsive
smart material for energy transduction and provides an in-depth understanding
of the responsive mechanism at the molecular level.

elements.content: Developing moisture-based energy-harvesting technologies has attracted extensive and intense attention attributed to its great application potential in both energy-related and wearable electronics fields. The key to achieving energy transduction depends on using advanced materials as the media. Smart materials, as a new generation of advanced materials, can undergo a reversible property change by external stimuli, such as heat, electricity, light, magnetism, and moisture. Recently, moisture-responsive smart materials have attracted widespread interest. As pioneering works, many efforts had been made to fabricate humidity-sensitive devices based on smart materials, including cellulose nanofibers, poly pyrrole, graphene, carbon nanotubes, poly dopamine, supramolecular crystals, and so on. Anisotropic and reversible absorption–desorption of water vapor by these actuators resulted in an impressive mechanical response. It has been demonstrated that these smart actuators were capable of converting the chemical potential of water into motion over a moist surface, which could be further converted into electrical energy. The performance of actuators depends on the speed and extent of the relative expansion and contraction of hygroscopic materials. However, the aforementioned moisture-responsive materials usually possess structures with no or low order that unavoidably cause unclear actuation mechanisms, impeding their application scopes. Thus, developing new moisture-responsive materials with well-defined mechanisms is highly important and urgent.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Developing moisture-based
energy-harvesting technologies has attracted
extensive and intense attention attributed to its great application
potential in both energy-related and wearable electronics fields. The key to achieving energy transduction depends
on using advanced materials as the media. Smart materials, as a new generation of advanced materials, can
undergo a reversible property change by external stimuli, such as
heat, electricity, light, magnetism, and moisture. Recently, moisture-responsive smart materials have attracted widespread
interest. As pioneering works, many efforts had been made to fabricate
humidity-sensitive devices based on smart materials, including cellulose
nanofibers, poly pyrrole, graphene, carbon nanotubes, poly dopamine, supramolecular crystals, and so on. Anisotropic and reversible absorption–desorption
of water vapor by these actuators resulted in an impressive mechanical
response. It has been demonstrated that these smart actuators were
capable of converting the chemical potential of water into motion
over a moist surface, which could be further converted into electrical
energy. The performance of actuators depends
on the speed and extent of the relative expansion and contraction
of hygroscopic materials. However, the aforementioned moisture-responsive
materials usually possess structures with no or low order that unavoidably
cause unclear actuation mechanisms, impeding their application scopes.
Thus, developing new moisture-responsive materials with well-defined
mechanisms is highly important and urgent.

elements.content: To address this matter, crystalline smart materials, as exemplified by soft porous crystals (SPCs), can be excellent candidates due to their well-defined structures, high porosity, structural flexibility, and so on. Moreover, the well-defined structures can facilitate the understanding of the response mechanism by means of in situ structural characterization and analysis. Currently, SPCs have mostly concentrated on the third-generation metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), i.e., flexible MOFs, which can undergo reversible phase transformations in response to external stimuli. Flexible MOFs hold great promise to overcome the shortcomings in the traditional moisture-responsive systems and significantly enhance their mechanical response because of the reversible deformation from the abrupt gate-opening effect, accompanied by a relatively large volume change. Although flexible MOFs with crystal volume changes upon external stimuli have been reported, their stimuli mainly include gases such as N2, CO2, and C2 and C3 hydrocarbons, and the stimuli-driven responses mostly occur under harsh conditions (e.g., low temperature or high pressure). Currently, moisture-responsive flexible MOFs with crystal volume changes have still very rarely been reported. Moreover, fabricating actuators based on crystalline materials, especially flexible MOFs that can convert the chemical potential of water into electrical energy, has not yet been investigated. In this contribution, we reported a flexible MOF, ZPF-2-Co (ZPF = zeolitic pyrimidine framework), which could undergo a reversible mechanical response upon moisture. In order to achieve energy transduction triggered by moisture (), a flexible, self-standing actuator was fabricated that showed reversible bending behavior upon varying the humidity gradient. Finally, we were able to generate electricity by means of coupling the mechanical actuator with a piezoelectric material. These results first demonstrated that flexible MOFs could be applied for humidity-driven electricity generation.
elements.clean_text:
To address this matter,
crystalline smart materials, as exemplified
by soft porous crystals (SPCs), can be excellent candidates due to
their well-defined structures, high porosity, structural flexibility,
and so on. Moreover, the well-defined structures
can facilitate the understanding of the response mechanism by means
of in situ structural characterization and analysis.
Currently, SPCs have mostly concentrated on the third-generation metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs), i.e., flexible MOFs, which can undergo reversible
phase transformations in response to external stimuli. Flexible MOFs hold great promise to overcome
the shortcomings in the traditional moisture-responsive systems and
significantly enhance their mechanical response because of the reversible
deformation from the abrupt gate-opening effect, accompanied by a
relatively large volume change. Although flexible MOFs with crystal
volume changes upon external stimuli have been reported, their stimuli
mainly include gases such as N2, CO2, and C2 and C3 hydrocarbons, and the stimuli-driven
responses mostly occur under harsh conditions (e.g., low temperature
or high pressure). Currently, moisture-responsive flexible MOFs with
crystal volume changes have still very rarely been reported. Moreover, fabricating actuators based on crystalline materials,
especially flexible MOFs that can convert the chemical potential of
water into electrical energy, has not yet been investigated. In this
contribution, we reported a flexible MOF, ZPF-2-Co (ZPF
= zeolitic pyrimidine framework), which could undergo a reversible
mechanical response upon moisture. In order to achieve energy transduction
triggered by moisture (), a flexible, self-standing actuator was fabricated that
showed reversible bending behavior upon varying the humidity gradient.
Finally, we were able to generate electricity by means of coupling
the mechanical actuator with a piezoelectric material. These results
first demonstrated that flexible MOFs could be applied for humidity-driven
electricity generation.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Construction of an Energy Transduction Pathway Based on Moisture-Responsive
MOFs, from Humidity Gradient to Mechanical Energy and Further to Electrical
Power</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ja1c01831_0005.tif" xlink:type="simple"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text:
1

Construction of an Energy Transduction Pathway Based on Moisture-Responsive
MOFs, from Humidity Gradient to Mechanical Energy and Further to Electrical
Power

elements.content: To develop flexible MOFs for energy transduction, the key to success is to construct MOFs with large unit cell volume variations upon moisture. After a comprehensive survey of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD), we found that a zeolitic MOF, ZPF-2-Co, could be an ideal candidate. ZPF-2-Co was prepared via a green synthesis approach: stirring an aqueous solution of 5-fluoropyrimidin-2-olate (F-pymo) and Co2+ salt at room temperature, using NaOH to adjust the pH of the solution. The precipitate was harvested by centrifugation and washed with deionized water. Although this powdery MOF with a simulated structure has been reported in the literature, its real single-crystal structure is has not been clear. Herein, for the first time, we obtained large single crystals for the hydrous ZPF-2-Co (named as ZPF-2-Co-α) via a diffusion method and determined its real structure via a single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) characterization. In the single-crystal structure of ZPF-2-Co-α, each Co2+ ion coordinates with four nitrogens from F-pymo in a slightly distorted tetrahedral fashion to form sodalite cages, hence fusing together to form a three-dimensional network with a sod topology ( and Table S1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion
Synthesis
and Characterization of Moisture-Responsive Flexible
MOFs
To develop flexible MOFs for energy transduction, the
key to success is to construct MOFs with large unit cell volume variations
upon moisture. After a comprehensive survey of the Cambridge Structural
Database (CSD), we found that a zeolitic MOF, ZPF-2-Co, could be an ideal candidate.
ZPF-2-Co was prepared via a green synthesis approach: stirring
an aqueous solution of 5-fluoropyrimidin-2-olate (F-pymo) and Co2+ salt at room temperature, using NaOH to adjust the pH of
the solution. The precipitate was harvested by centrifugation and
washed with deionized water. Although this powdery MOF with a simulated
structure has been reported in the literature, its real single-crystal structure is has not been clear.
Herein, for the first time, we obtained large single crystals for
the hydrous ZPF-2-Co (named as ZPF-2-Co-α) via a diffusion method and determined its real structure via a
single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) characterization. In the
single-crystal structure of ZPF-2-Co-α, each Co2+ ion coordinates with four nitrogens from F-pymo in a slightly
distorted tetrahedral fashion to form sodalite cages, hence fusing
together to form a three-dimensional network with a sod topology ( and Table S1).

elements.content: (top) Structure transformation from ZPF-2-Co-α to ZPF-2-Co-β. (bottom) PXRD patterns of ZPF-2-Co-α, ZPF-2-Co-β, and their calculated or simulated patterns. Atom colors: cobalt, pink; carbon, gray; nitrogen, blue; oxygen, red; fluorine, green.
elements.clean_text:
1

(top) Structure transformation
from ZPF-2-Co-α to ZPF-2-Co-β. (bottom) PXRD patterns of ZPF-2-Co-α, ZPF-2-Co-β, and their
calculated or simulated patterns. Atom colors: cobalt, pink; carbon,
gray; nitrogen, blue; oxygen, red; fluorine, green.

elements.content: The stability evaluation revealed that ZPF-2-Co-α was stable in water or in a pH 4–9 aqueous solution for 24 h, as verified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Figure S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed that ZPF-2-Co-α underwent a weight loss of ∼14% at 333 K due to the loss of guest water molecules (Figure S2). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra showed the disappearance of characteristic water peaks (∼3300 cm–1), further confirming the loss of guest water molecules upon heating (Figure S3). Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images showed that ZPF-2-Co possessed approximately 10–30 μm sized particles of polyhedral shape before and after the dehydration process (Figure S4). Interestingly, after the thermal and vacuum treatments, PXRD patterns indicated that a dehydrated phase (named ZPF-2-Co-β) formed. As shown in , ZPF-2-Co-β showed a pattern that fit well with the pattern from the theoretical simulation obtained by TOPAS-R in the literature. A comparison of the structures of ZPF-2-Co-α and -β revealed that the F-pymo ligand rotated, accompanied by a change in the bond angles (Co–N bonds) (Figure S5). That is, the sodalite cages were squeezed upon the phase change, causing the main topological feature to be unaltered. The unit cell volume variation (Δ) from ZPF-2-Co-β (4985.2 Å3) to ZPF-2-Co-α (5794.9 Å3) was 16.2% (Table S2), suitable for a swelling medium. All of these results indicate that ZPF-2-Co with a flexible structure should be an ideal platform for stimuli–response-related applications.
elements.clean_text:
The stability evaluation revealed that ZPF-2-Co-α was stable in water or in a pH 4–9 aqueous solution for 24
h, as verified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Figure S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed that ZPF-2-Co-α underwent a weight loss of ∼14% at
333 K due to the loss of guest water molecules (Figure S2). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR)
spectra showed the disappearance of characteristic water peaks (∼3300
cm–1), further confirming the loss of guest water
molecules upon heating (Figure S3). Scanning
electron microscope (SEM) images showed that ZPF-2-Co possessed approximately 10–30 μm sized particles of
polyhedral shape before and after the dehydration process (Figure S4). Interestingly, after the thermal
and vacuum treatments, PXRD patterns indicated that a dehydrated phase
(named ZPF-2-Co-β) formed. As shown in , ZPF-2-Co-β showed a pattern that fit well with the pattern from the theoretical
simulation obtained by TOPAS-R in the literature. A comparison of the structures of ZPF-2-Co-α and -β revealed that the F-pymo ligand rotated,
accompanied by a change in the bond angles (Co–N bonds) (Figure S5). That is, the sodalite cages were
squeezed upon the phase change, causing the main topological feature
to be unaltered. The unit cell volume variation (Δ) from ZPF-2-Co-β (4985.2 Å3) to ZPF-2-Co-α (5794.9 Å3) was 16.2% (Table S2), suitable for a swelling medium. All of these results indicate
that ZPF-2-Co with a flexible structure should be an
ideal platform for stimuli–response-related applications.

elements.content: The as-synthesized MOF was then activated for gas sorption studies by degassing under a dynamic vacuum at 373 K for 12 h. N2 sorption at 77 K revealed that the dehydrated ZPF-2-Co-β did not adsorb a significant amount of N2. In contrast, the CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherm collected at 195 K showed there was a steep increase in uptake (10 cm3 g–1) in the low-pressure range up to ∼10 kPa, and then above this threshold pressure, there was another steep increase in uptake, reaching a value of 110 cm3 g–1 at 101 kPa. The abrupt gate-opening effect (Figure S6) indicated the existence of a flexible structure. Vacuum dynamic vapor sorption (DVS) experiments were then conducted at ambient temperature from vacuum to 95% relative humidity (RH) (2.85 kPa) to evaluate the water vapor adsorption performance. ZPF-2-Co-β possessed a water sorption isotherm that showed little water uptake up to RH = 10%, followed by a steep uptake, and then reached the maximum uptake of 230 mg g–1 at RH = 95%. This result indicated a gate-opening effect accompanied by a structural transformation during the adsorption of water vapor. The desorption isotherm showed a small hysteresis with steep desorption at a RH of ∼5%. This result indicated that the adsorbed water molecules could be easily and completely removed from the pores (a). Moreover, we also tested the uptake quantities and speed of water vapor by ZPF-2-Co-β under dynamic flow conditions at 298 K using the gravimetric method. For this experiment, N2 gas carrying water vapor (RH = 30%), the watershed to evaluate if adsorbents are suitable for water harvesting from the air, was passed over the activated MOF sample (activation detailed in Supporting Information). As shown in b, ZPF-2-Co-β not only can capture water vapor from the gaseous stream (RH = 30%) in less than 10 min until 15 wt % but also can be regenerated in less than 20 min once the RH is decreased to approach 0%. This excellent performance allowed harvesting of an extrapolated amount of 7.20 L of water per kilogram of MOF per day. This remarkable performance surpasses most of the benchmark MOF desiccants such as MOF-801 and Co 2 Cl 2 BTDD and even some commercial sorbents such as Basolite A520, zeolite SAPO-34, and zeolite 13X for the arid environment, only being lower than MOF-303 (thin layer) (c). In order to evaluate the reusability and stability of ZPF-2-Co-β, recycling the adsorption and desorption of water vapor for 50 cycles was further checked. Impressively, we found that ZPF-2-Co-β could complete the whole process in less than 40 min for each cycle without significant loss of the working capacities within the total span of measurements (d). In addition, we found that the characteristic PXRD peaks of ZPF-2-Co-β and ZPF-2-Co-α alternately appeared during the recycling tests, indicative of the high durability of the ZPF-2-Co platform (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text:
Water Sorption and Harvesting Experiments
The as-synthesized
MOF was then activated for gas sorption studies by degassing under
a dynamic vacuum at 373 K for 12 h. N2 sorption at 77 K
revealed that the dehydrated ZPF-2-Co-β did not
adsorb a significant amount of N2. In contrast, the CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherm collected at 195 K
showed there was a steep increase in uptake (10 cm3 g–1) in the low-pressure range up to ∼10 kPa,
and then above this threshold pressure, there was another steep increase
in uptake, reaching a value of 110 cm3 g–1 at 101 kPa. The abrupt gate-opening effect (Figure S6) indicated the existence of a flexible structure.
Vacuum dynamic vapor sorption (DVS) experiments were then conducted
at ambient temperature from vacuum to 95% relative humidity (RH) (2.85
kPa) to evaluate the water vapor adsorption performance. ZPF-2-Co-β possessed a water sorption isotherm that showed little water uptake
up to RH = 10%, followed by a steep uptake, and then reached the maximum
uptake of 230 mg g–1 at RH = 95%. This result indicated
a gate-opening effect accompanied by a structural transformation during
the adsorption of water vapor. The desorption isotherm showed a small
hysteresis with steep desorption at a RH of ∼5%. This result
indicated that the adsorbed water molecules could be easily and completely
removed from the pores (a). Moreover, we also tested the uptake quantities and speed
of water vapor by ZPF-2-Co-β under dynamic flow
conditions at 298 K using the gravimetric method. For this experiment,
N2 gas carrying water vapor (RH = 30%), the watershed to
evaluate if adsorbents are suitable for water harvesting from the
air, was passed over the activated MOF
sample (activation detailed in Supporting Information). As shown in b, ZPF-2-Co-β not only can capture water vapor
from the gaseous stream (RH = 30%) in less than 10 min until 15 wt
% but also can be regenerated in less than 20 min once the RH is decreased
to approach 0%. This excellent performance allowed harvesting of an
extrapolated amount of 7.20 L of water per kilogram of MOF per day.
This remarkable performance surpasses most of the benchmark MOF desiccants
such as MOF-801
 and Co

2

Cl

2

BTDD
 and even some
commercial sorbents such as Basolite A520, zeolite SAPO-34, and zeolite 13X for the arid environment,
only being lower than MOF-303 (thin layer) (c). In order to evaluate the reusability and stability of ZPF-2-Co-β, recycling the adsorption and desorption of water vapor for 50 cycles
was further checked. Impressively, we found that ZPF-2-Co-β could complete the whole process in less than 40 min for each cycle
without significant loss of the working capacities within the total
span of measurements (d). In addition, we found that the characteristic PXRD peaks
of ZPF-2-Co-β and ZPF-2-Co-α alternately appeared during the recycling tests, indicative of the
high durability of the ZPF-2-Co platform (Figure S7).

elements.content: (a) Vacuum DVS isotherms of ZPF-2-Co. (b) Dynamic adsorption–desorption curves of ZPF-2-Co. (c) Comparison of the daily water uptake of ZPF-2-Co with those of other representative MOFs or commercial desiccants for anarid environment. Conditions: MOF-303 (thin layer), RH = 30%, 303 K to RH = 0%, 358 K; ZPF-2-Co, RH = 0 to 30%, 298 K; MOF-801, RH = 20%, 298 to 338 K; Co 2 Cl 2 BTDD, RH = 35%, 298 K to RH = 5%, 318 K; Basolite A520, zeolite SAPO-34, and zeolite 13X: RH = 30%, 303 K to RH = 0%, 358 K in packed bed. (d) Dynamic adsorption–desorption curves of ZPF-2-Co over 50 cycles.

adsorption–desorption curves of ZPF-2-Co. (c)

those of other representative MOFs or commercial desiccants for anarid

= 30%, 303 K to RH = 0%, 358 K in packed bed. (d) Dynamic adsorption–desorption

elements.content: The fast kinetics of water uptake and release can benefit the ZPF-2-Co sorbent in harvesting water. Moreover, the green and straightforward synthesis approach makes ZPF-2-Co suitable for large-scale production. On the basis of all these considerations, ZPF-2-Co is a perfect platform for water harvesting from arid air. In daily life, these responses could be finished with the assistance of heating to mimic the humidity change. Thereupon, 0.500 g of dehydrated ZPF-2-Co-β was placed in a homemade device with RH = 30% atmosphere for 30 min to ensure that vapor adsorbed into the samples by diffusion (Figure S8). After saturation, the hydrated ZPF-2-Co-α was heated at 353 K for 15 min to release the adsorbed water vapor, which was further condensed and collected. After five cycles, the actual harvestable quantity of water was estimated to be 0.240 kg of water per kg of MOF (Figure S9), while no water was harvested in the blank control. Not surprisingly, the amount of water harvested by the real experimental device, 1.54 L kg–1 day–1, was lower than the calculated value, 7.20 L kg–1 day–1. This result agreed with the literature results and could be because not all of the MOF particles were accessible in the sorbent bed. Developing better MOF formulations that will gather more water from arid air is ongoing in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
The fast kinetics of water uptake and release can benefit the ZPF-2-Co sorbent in harvesting water. Moreover, the green
and straightforward synthesis approach makes ZPF-2-Co suitable for large-scale production. On the basis of all these considerations, ZPF-2-Co is a perfect platform for water harvesting from arid
air. In daily life, these responses could be finished with the assistance
of heating to mimic the humidity change. Thereupon, 0.500 g of dehydrated ZPF-2-Co-β was placed in a homemade device with RH =
30% atmosphere for 30 min to ensure that vapor adsorbed into the samples
by diffusion (Figure S8). After saturation,
the hydrated ZPF-2-Co-α was heated at 353 K for
15 min to release the adsorbed water vapor, which was further condensed
and collected. After five cycles, the actual harvestable quantity
of water was estimated to be 0.240 kg of water per kg of MOF (Figure S9), while no water was harvested in the
blank control. Not surprisingly, the amount of water harvested by
the real experimental device, 1.54 L kg–1 day–1, was lower than the calculated value, 7.20 L kg–1 day–1. This result agreed with
the literature results and could be because not all
of the MOF particles were accessible in the sorbent bed. Developing
better MOF formulations that will gather more water from arid air
is ongoing in our laboratory.

elements.content: The mechanical responses of flexible MOF crystals are usually minimal and have difficulty in performing useful work. It is very challenging to construct macroscale artificial actuators with a large deformation based on nano- or microscale crystals, mainly due to the lack of suitable strategies. In our previous work, inspired by muscle components, we created a mixed-matrix strategy to fabricate photoresponsive “crystalline artificial muscles”. Following the same line, herein, we deliberately mixed MOF crystals with connective polymers that can converge crystal motions into one synergetic system. Polymers can mimic connective tissues, and MOF crystals can act as muscle cells in the hybrid actuator. The hybrid system of poly­(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) and ZPF-2-Co was chosen as a representative to study their performance in detail. We reviewed all of the parameters, including particle size, loading amounts, and actuator thickness, to determine the actuators with optimized performance. First, the influence of particle size was investigated. The pristine ZPF-2-Co (∼10 μm) was ground to a smaller size (∼1 μm) (Table S3). PXRD patterns revealed that its crystallinity was retained after the grinding treatment (Figure S10). Interestingly, the membranes with the pristine crystals as the fillers showed bending deformation (0.11 cm–1 curvature within 10 min) upon moisture stimulus, while the membranes with the smaller particles as the fillers did not show any deformation upon the same treatment (Figures S11 and S12 and Table S3). The SEM images and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping results (Figure S13) of the top, bottom, and cross-section of the membranes revealed that the ground particles were nearly uniformly dispersed in the hybrid membrane. In contrast, the pristine MOF particles were mainly located in the region close to the bottom layer (Figure S14), as indicated by the distribution of the characteristic Co element (inside a). This could be because the pristine MOF particles were much larger and denser than the smaller particles, hence easily leading to the particle settlement. These results showed that the membrane with a gradient distribution of MOF particles was beneficial for moisture-responsive deformation.
elements.clean_text:
Constructing Moisture-Responsive
Actuators
The mechanical
responses of flexible MOF crystals are usually minimal and have difficulty
in performing useful work. It is very challenging to construct macroscale
artificial actuators with a large deformation based on nano- or microscale
crystals, mainly due to the lack of suitable strategies. In our previous
work, inspired by muscle components, we created a mixed-matrix strategy
to fabricate photoresponsive “crystalline artificial muscles”. Following the same line, herein, we deliberately mixed MOF crystals
with connective polymers that can converge crystal motions into one
synergetic system. Polymers can mimic connective tissues, and MOF
crystals can act as muscle cells in the hybrid actuator. The hybrid
system of poly­(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) and ZPF-2-Co was
chosen as a representative to study their performance in detail. We
reviewed all of the parameters, including particle size, loading amounts,
and actuator thickness, to determine the actuators with optimized
performance. First, the influence of particle size was investigated.
The pristine ZPF-2-Co (∼10 μm) was ground
to a smaller size (∼1 μm) (Table S3). PXRD patterns revealed that its crystallinity was retained
after the grinding treatment (Figure S10). Interestingly, the membranes with the pristine crystals as the
fillers showed bending deformation (0.11 cm–1 curvature
within 10 min) upon moisture stimulus, while the membranes with the
smaller particles as the fillers did not show any deformation upon
the same treatment (Figures S11 and S12 and Table S3). The SEM images and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping
results (Figure S13) of the top, bottom,
and cross-section of the membranes revealed that the ground particles
were nearly uniformly dispersed in the hybrid membrane. In contrast,
the pristine MOF particles were mainly located in the region close
to the bottom layer (Figure S14), as indicated
by the distribution of the characteristic Co element (inside a). This could be
because the pristine MOF particles were much larger and denser than
the smaller particles, hence easily leading to the particle settlement.
These results showed that the membrane with a gradient distribution
of MOF particles was beneficial for moisture-responsive deformation.

elements.content: (a) Demonstration of the membrane with a gradient distribution of MOF particles being beneficial for moisture-responsive deformation (e.g., bending): (top) optical image of PVA-ZPF-2-Co; (bottom) SEM images and EDX mapping of Co element in the cross-section of the membrane. (b) Initial states (top) and final states (bottom) for PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuators under different RHs for 10 min. (c) Curvatures of the PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuator under RH = 0–30% during 10 repeated cycles.

RH = 0–30% during 10 repeated cycles.

elements.content: Next, we optimized the ratio of ZPF-2-Co particles and PVA and the thickness of membranes. After systematic studies, it was found that a ratio of 1:2 (wt %) (Figures S15 and S16 and Table S4) and a membrane thickness of ∼135 μm (Figures S17 and S18 and Table S5) afforded superior comprehensive properties. The FTIR spectrum of PVA-ZPF-2-Co showed features that were present for both ZPF-2-Co and PVA. No apparent shifts in the bands were observed (Figure S19), suggesting the absence of strong polymer–MOF interactions. This indicated that the shape change of PVA-ZPF-2-Co mainly relied on the crystal size change of ZPF-2-Co embedded in PVA, rather than an interaction between the polymer and MOFs. To further optimize the hybrid system, various hydrophilic connective polymers, including PVA, polyethylene glycol (PEG), and carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), were chosen and evaluated. It was found that, upon the same moisture treatment, PVA-ZPF-2-Co showed a much larger curvature in comparison to those of PEG- and CMC-ZPF-2-Co actuators, indicating the better performance of the PVA hybrid system (Figure S20). Moreover, to demonstrate if the actuators could perform useful works, e.g., lifting weight, we compared the ability of PEG-, PVA-, and CMC-ZPF-2-Co actuators and their blank controls to lift weights with a certain quality and then investigated the relationships between curvatures and mass of weights quantitatively. The results showed PVA-ZPF-2-Co could lift a weight of at least 50 mg (Figure S21), while PEG- and CMC-ZPF-2-Co actuators and blank polymers were nearly inert. As predicted, for PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuators, the curvatures decreased along with the increased mass of the weight (Figure S22 and Table S6). Thereupon, PVA, having the best performance, was selected as the connective polymer in the following studies.
elements.clean_text:
Next, we optimized the ratio of ZPF-2-Co particles
and PVA and the thickness of membranes. After systematic studies,
it was found that a ratio of 1:2 (wt %) (Figures S15 and S16 and Table S4) and a membrane thickness of ∼135
μm (Figures S17 and S18 and Table S5) afforded superior comprehensive properties. The FTIR spectrum of PVA-ZPF-2-Co showed features that were present for both ZPF-2-Co and PVA. No apparent shifts in the bands were observed
(Figure S19), suggesting the absence of
strong polymer–MOF interactions. This indicated that the shape change of PVA-ZPF-2-Co mainly relied on the crystal size change of ZPF-2-Co embedded in PVA, rather than an interaction between the polymer
and MOFs. To further optimize the hybrid system, various hydrophilic
connective polymers, including PVA, polyethylene glycol (PEG), and
carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), were chosen and evaluated. It was found
that, upon the same moisture treatment, PVA-ZPF-2-Co showed
a much larger curvature in comparison to those of PEG- and CMC-ZPF-2-Co actuators, indicating the better performance
of the PVA hybrid system (Figure S20).
Moreover, to demonstrate if the actuators could perform useful works,
e.g., lifting weight, we compared the ability of PEG-, PVA-, and CMC-ZPF-2-Co actuators and
their blank controls to lift weights with a certain quality and then
investigated the relationships between curvatures and mass of weights
quantitatively. The results showed PVA-ZPF-2-Co could
lift a weight of at least 50 mg (Figure S21), while PEG- and CMC-ZPF-2-Co actuators
and blank polymers were nearly inert. As predicted, for PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuators, the curvatures decreased along with the increased mass
of the weight (Figure S22 and Table S6).
Thereupon, PVA, having the best performance, was selected as the connective
polymer in the following studies.

elements.content: On the basis of the optimized actuator determined in the above systematic studies, we further investigated the influence of different RHs on the actuator’s performance. We compared the curvature of PVA-ZPF-2-Co with that of a blank PVA membrane. The results showed that there was nearly no obvious deformation for the membranes if RH < 10%. Along with an increase in RH, the curvature of PVA-ZPF-2-Co also rose. In contrast, the blank PVA membrane was inert under the same treatments (Figures S23 and S24 and Table S7). This could be because the vapor diffusion rate into the hybrid membranes was accelerated as the RH was increased (b and Figure S24 and Table S7). To further prove this hypothesis, we kept the actuator at 11% RH for 45 min and found that this actuator indeed achieved a curvature close to that at 33% RH for 10 min (Figure S25). These results revealed that the mechanical response of PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuator originated from ZPF-2-Co crystals, not PVA polymer. In addition, the cycling test of the actuator under RH = 0–30% suggested that the hybrid membrane can perform repeated deformations (i.e., bending–straightening) for at least 10 cycles without significant decay, indicating an excellent reusability and stability of the actuator (c). Moreover, after the cycling tests, the PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuator can still retain its crystallinity, as confirmed by the PXRD test (Figure S26).
elements.clean_text:
On the basis of the optimized
actuator determined in the above
systematic studies, we further investigated the influence of different
RHs on the actuator’s performance. We compared the curvature
of PVA-ZPF-2-Co with that of a blank PVA membrane. The
results showed that there was nearly no obvious deformation for the
membranes if RH < 10%. Along with an increase in RH, the curvature
of PVA-ZPF-2-Co also rose. In contrast, the blank PVA
membrane was inert under the same treatments (Figures S23 and S24 and Table S7). This could be because the
vapor diffusion rate into the hybrid membranes was accelerated as
the RH was increased (b and Figure S24 and Table S7).
To further prove this hypothesis, we kept the actuator at 11% RH for
45 min and found that this actuator indeed achieved a curvature close
to that at 33% RH for 10 min (Figure S25). These results revealed that the mechanical response of PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuator originated from ZPF-2-Co crystals, not PVA
polymer. In addition, the cycling test of the actuator under RH =
0–30% suggested that the hybrid membrane can perform repeated
deformations (i.e., bending–straightening) for at least 10
cycles without significant decay, indicating an excellent reusability
and stability of the actuator (c). Moreover, after the cycling tests, the PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuator can still retain its crystallinity, as confirmed by the
PXRD test (Figure S26).

elements.content: The periodic deformation of the PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuator driven by moisture could be utilized to transduce the chemical potential of water into mechanical energy, further converting it into electrical energy. As a demonstration of this actuator’s capability to generate electricity, the actuator was coupled with the piezoelectric polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), which can convert the mechanical force of the PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuator into electrical power (Figure S27). Under the periodic variations of RH (0–30%) in the environment, the coupled actuator repeatedly bent and stretched the piezoelectric PVDF (a), resulting in reversible bending movements with a continuous output of electrical signals. Each cycle produced an open-circuit voltage of up to 20 mV for the peak output of adsorption (b) or reached to −20 mV at the end of desorption (Figure S28), and at least 10 cycles could be executed without an obvious decay. A 1 MΩ resistor was loaded onto this generator, and the peak output reached ∼7 mV, which meant I = 7 nA. Thus, the average power output was approximately 0.049 nW, which corresponded to a power or energy density of 2.45 μW kg–1 or 0.34 μWh kg–1. In contrast, the same setup with PVDF coupled with a blank PVA membrane did not show significant signals due to the inertness of PVA with moisture. These results presented here highlighted the great potential to use moisture-responsive MOF actuators to generate clean energy, which deserves more effort in the future.
elements.clean_text:
Coupling an
Actuator with Piezoelectric PVDF to Generate Electricity
The periodic deformation of the PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuator
driven by moisture could be utilized to transduce the chemical potential
of water into mechanical energy, further converting it into electrical
energy. As a demonstration of this actuator’s capability to
generate electricity, the actuator was coupled with the piezoelectric
polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), which can convert the mechanical force
of the PVA-ZPF-2-Co actuator into electrical power (Figure S27). Under the periodic variations of
RH (0–30%) in the environment, the coupled actuator repeatedly
bent and stretched the piezoelectric PVDF (a), resulting in reversible bending movements
with a continuous output of electrical signals. Each cycle produced
an open-circuit voltage of up to 20 mV for the peak output of adsorption
(b) or reached
to −20 mV at the end of desorption (Figure S28), and at least 10 cycles could be executed without an obvious
decay. A 1 MΩ resistor was loaded onto this generator, and the
peak output reached ∼7 mV, which meant I =
7 nA. Thus, the average power output was approximately 0.049 nW, which
corresponded to a power or energy density of 2.45 μW kg–1 or 0.34 μWh kg–1. In contrast,
the same setup with PVDF coupled with a blank PVA membrane did not
show significant signals due to the inertness of PVA with moisture.
These results presented here highlighted the great potential to use
moisture-responsive MOF actuators to generate clean energy, which
deserves more effort in the future.

elements.content: (a) Time-dependent deformation of the piezoelectric PVDF/PVA-ZPF-2-Co hybrid system upon periodic exposure to RH = 0% or 30%. (b) Open-circuit voltage signals generated by PVDF/PVA-ZPF-2-Co at moist air exposure intervals.
elements.clean_text:
4

(a) Time-dependent deformation of the
piezoelectric PVDF/PVA-ZPF-2-Co hybrid system upon periodic
exposure to RH = 0% or 30%. (b) Open-circuit
voltage signals generated by PVDF/PVA-ZPF-2-Co at moist
air exposure intervals.

elements.content: In summary, in order to construct an energy transduction pathway from humidity gradient to electrical power, a flexible MOF (ZPF-2-Co) with a zeolitic sod network was constructed to serve as the energy conversion medium. It was found that this flexible MOF can undergo a reversible phase transformation with a large change of unit cell volume (up to 16.2%) upon hydration (α phase) and dehydration (β phase). A dynamic water vapor sorption examination revealed that the dehydrated ZPF-2-Co showed a structure-related gate-opening effect (β → α phase) with a steep water uptake and could complete the whole adsorption–desorption cycle within 30 min under dynamic flow conditions. This fast adsorption–desorption process allowed harvesting an extrapolated 7.2 L water per kilogram of MOF per day, surpassing most reported MOF desiccants and even some commercial sorbents for an arid environment, only being lower than that of MOF-303 (thin layer). A moisture-responsive actuator (PVA-ZPF-2-Co) was then fabricated by hybridizing a PVA polymer with ZPF-2-Co particles, which exhibited a gradient distribution in the polymer matrix. We found that this gradient distributed structure was beneficial to convert humidity-triggered expansion/contraction of MOF particles into large macroscopic deformations. This mechanical actuator showed excellent reusability and stability. Furthermore, this mechanical actuator was coupled with a piezoelectric transducer (PVDF) into an electrical generator that successfully converted the mechanical work into electrical power. The output voltage could be controlled by adjusting the bending degree or speed of the composite bilayer through a variation of the environmental RH. This study creates a new avenue to fabricate moisture-responsive actuators that can transduce the chemical potential of water into electricity and broadens the application scope of MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In
summary, in order to construct an energy transduction pathway
from humidity gradient to electrical power, a flexible MOF (ZPF-2-Co) with a zeolitic sod network was constructed
to serve as the energy conversion medium. It was found that this flexible
MOF can undergo a reversible phase transformation with a large change
of unit cell volume (up to 16.2%) upon hydration (α phase) and
dehydration (β phase). A dynamic water vapor sorption examination
revealed that the dehydrated ZPF-2-Co showed a structure-related
gate-opening effect (β → α phase) with a steep
water uptake and could complete the whole adsorption–desorption
cycle within 30 min under dynamic flow conditions. This fast adsorption–desorption
process allowed harvesting an extrapolated 7.2 L water per kilogram
of MOF per day, surpassing most reported MOF desiccants and even some
commercial sorbents for an arid environment, only being lower than
that of MOF-303 (thin layer). A moisture-responsive actuator
(PVA-ZPF-2-Co) was then fabricated by hybridizing a PVA
polymer with ZPF-2-Co particles, which exhibited a gradient
distribution in the polymer matrix. We found that this gradient distributed
structure was beneficial to convert humidity-triggered expansion/contraction
of MOF particles into large macroscopic deformations. This mechanical
actuator showed excellent reusability and stability. Furthermore,
this mechanical actuator was coupled with a piezoelectric transducer
(PVDF) into an electrical generator that successfully converted the
mechanical work into electrical power. The output voltage could be
controlled by adjusting the bending degree or speed of the composite
bilayer through a variation of the environmental RH. This study creates
a new avenue to fabricate moisture-responsive actuators that can transduce
the chemical potential of water into electricity and broadens the
application scope of MOFs.

metadata.title:
Fabrication
of Moisture-Responsive Crystalline Smart
Materials for Water Harvesting and Electricity Transduction
